# Introduction

We have learnt that the MGF for a binimial random variable is:

$$M_X(t) = (q+pe^t)^n $$

Where $X\sim Bin(n,p)$

# Tasks

Using the moment generating function above prove that 

$$\sigma^2 = npq$$

by answering the tasks below. 
Use $\LaTeX$ to construct the proof for Task 1.

## Task 1

Start with 

$$
\begin{eqnarray}
E(X) &=& \left . \frac{d M_X(t)}{dt}\right |_{t=0}\\
&=& n\left(p\mathrm{e}^t+q\right)^{n-1}p\mathrm{e}^t\\
&=& n\left(p\mathrm{e}^0+q\right)^{n-1}{pe^0}\\
&=& \displaystyle{\displaylines{np(p+q)^{n-1}}}\\
&=& \displaystyle{\displaylines{np(1)^{n-1}}}\\
&=& \displaystyle{\displaylines{np}}\\
\mu_1' &=& \mu = \left . \frac{d M_X(t)}{dt}\right |_{t=0} = np\\
E(X) &=& \mu_1'
\end{eqnarray}

$$

## Task 2

You may use paper and write neatly the proof - take a picture and place in the document using 

`![](){}`

Now find $E(X^2)$

$$
\begin{eqnarray}
E(X^2) &=&  \left . \frac{d^2 M_X(t)}{dt^2}\right |_{t=0}\\
&=& np\frac{\ d}{dt}{[e^t(pe^t + q)^{n-1}]} |_{t=0}\\
&=& np{[e^t(n-1)(pe^t + q)^{n-2}pe^t+(pe^t+q)^{n-1}e^t]} |_{t=0}\\
&=& np{[(1)(n-1)(1)p+(1)(1)]}\\
&=& np[(n-1)p+1]\\
&=& np(np-p+1)\\
&=& np(np+q)\\
&=& n^2p^2+npq\\
\mu_2' &=&   \left . \frac{d^2 M_X(t)}{dt^2}\right |_{t=0}= n^2p^2+npq\\
E(X^2) &=& \mu_2'
\end{eqnarray}
$$

## Task 3

Find $\sigma^2$ Using the formula $\sigma^2 =E(X^2)-\mu^2$

$$
\begin{eqnarray}
\sigma^2 &=&E(X^2)-\mu^2 = \mu_2'-(\mu_1')^2\\
\end{eqnarray}

$$

Substituting the $\mu_2'$ values of and $\mu_1' = \mu$
$$
\begin{eqnarray}
\sigma^2 &=& n^2p^2 + npq-(np)^2 = npq\\
\end{eqnarray}

$$
